title: In the Drops: Garmin Fenix 8 mega watch, nifty Ogio Alpha backpack, Columbia sandals, Sidi’s most expensive shoes, and pigeons and a pistol
content:
Cyclist
In the Drops: Garmin Fenix 8 mega watch, nifty Ogio Alpha backpack, Columbia sandals, Sidi’s most expensive shoes, and pigeons and a pistol

Welcome back, it’s Friday, I’m doing In the Drops and wow, what a week it’s been at Cyclist towers.

I sat down with Bradley Wiggins for episode 131 of the Cyclist Magazine Podcast, who spoke candidly about his frictions with Team Sky, his regrets around speaking about Lance Armstrong, and how hard life has been off the bike – but how high those moments were on it. Give it a listen, it’s great (I’m not biased). We’re also on YouTube if you want to look at me old boat race.

We’ve also got all the latest news plus what’s to come at the Giro d’Italia, as well as the best all-road bikes reviewed… because we all need a new bike and all-road is different from anything you’ve ridden or owned before – even that endurance bike. Plus we also have a review of one of my favourite current bikes –  just for its pedigree and how it looks, because I’m shallow – the Parlee Ouray.

So go read, watch and listen, but not before you cast your windows to the soul over In the Drops.

Garmin Fenix 8 adventure watch

I’m going to write an in-depth review on Garmin’s new multi-sport smartwatch soon, so stay tuned, but here are some initial thoughts in the meantime…

The new Fenix 8 already feels like a serious step up from the Garmin Epix 2 and Fenix 7. The full colour touchscreen is offered in three sizes, 43mm, 47mm and 51mm, with this being the 51mm, and it is big. But it also doesn’t feel unwieldy, and while nominal measurements are the same as the Epix 2 and outgoing Fenix, the actual screen is much bigger. Like for like, the Fenix 8 is 1.4in (size 51mm) whereas the Fenix 7 screen is 1.3in, and though just 0.1in bigger, it has the comparative feel of going from a ‘Mini’ iPhone to a Max or Pro. Compared to the smaller Fenix 8s, the 51mm also has longer battery life.

The screen is bold, bright, high-definition and available either as AMOLED, which is brighter and crisper and always on, or Solar, where the whole face is photovoltaic to charge the watch as you go. That said, Solar won’t charge more quickly than it drains, although users report a 30-40% better battery for the Fenix 8 Solar vs the AMOLED.

Hence this is the Solar, as I’m all for battery life, especially as my trusty Epix 2 has long ago taken the place of my head unit for riding – all save for moments when turn-by-turn mapping is needed.

So the Fenix 8 Solar’s runtime should be up to 48 days as a smartwatch (eg, notifications, basic tracking like step count and sleep) or anything from 68-186 hours of GPS use, depending on things like using the multi-band satellites (it can fix using GPS, GLONASS and Galileo), which afford greater accuracy and faster locating when switching on to record a ride.

The list of features is exhaustive, from modes to cover every sport imaginable to sleep tracking to being a little personal trainer in your pocket (well, on your wrist), providing daily workouts based on your long-term goals and your conditioning that day (itself based on previous workouts and sleep).

There’s way too much to go into here, suffice to say this is already the smartest watch I’ve ever used. The screen is superb, it has point-to-point breadcrumb mapping, it has 32GB of storage so you can listen to Spotify with just paired headphones and no need for a phone. And it has built-in speaker for tiny raves on board whatever dive boat you’re on before you drop down into the briny water and watch the depth gauge tell you how underneath the sea you are.

And it has a little in-built flash.

Check back in a few weeks for a proper review.

  • Buy now from Garmin from £879.99

Ogio Alpha Venture backpack

For the longest time I’ve air-travelled with an Ogio duffel in the hold (the Ogio Endurance 9.0 since you ask), and after a decade of tête-à-têtes with baggage handlers, it’s ceded only two zip loops and a superficial rip. It has performed valiantly, and I’m not about to retire it yet.

But I’m about to add the 38-litre Ogio Alpha Venture backpack to my travel-bag arsenal, which I feel confident will stand up just as well as travel luggage or race-day kit luggage.

In short: the build quality seems there, and the pocket and strap arrangement is clever and comfortable in typical Ogio style. In long, read on…

Build quality feels top notch – I say ‘feels’ as this is early days, but the Alpha backpack has a nice, canvas-like sensibility to it, with a high-density recycled polyester bottom, designed to put up with being put down, and a lighter-density recycled polyester main-frame. As such it weighs just under 1.5kg, which in my experience is pretty light for any decently-robust 38-litre backpack, let alone one with so many partitions, pockets and features.

The Alpha folds out a bit like a clamshell wheelie case, the two halves secured by reinforced bi-directional zippers and four clip straps – which also double as places to carry items like a sleeping mat or rolled up towel. Inside are two main, zipped, mesh-topped compartments plus two flat pockets and a third zip pocket.

Accessible from the exterior of the bag is a top zip pocket, a laptop sleeve side zip pocket, a passport/wallet zip pocket, another front zip pocket and a water bottle side pocket.

The shoulder straps are wide, padded and comfy, and can be zipped away so they don’t get stuck on luggage carousels if going in an aeroplane hold (there is a side handle and top handle to carry it like this). Positionable on various parts of the shoulder straps is a removable valuables zip pocket for things like keys, then there are the two stabilising straps, chest and waist.

The latter is rather neat as, pull at the waist strap from one side and out pops a mini-sling/bum-bag that Velcros in when not in use.

As mentioned, this is a 38-litre version. The Alpha Mini backpack (9-litre, £59) and Alpha 20l backpack (20-litre, £89) complete the set.

  • Buy now from Ogio for £129

Columbia Konos Hiker 2-Strap sandals

Who doesn’t need sandals? People who love athlete’s foot, or who hate transitioning easily from sea to rocks to country path, or who just plain hate the freedom of airy toes.

Me, I love a good pair of sandals, and these Columbia Konos seem just the ticket.

First up, I’ve been suffering from plantar fasciitis for the last few months, which is brought on by (so my podiatrist tells me) walking around in shoes with poor arch support, or bare feet. Rats! For the inverse of the reasons above. However, the Konos have so far proved to offer excellent arch-support, from an in-sole that Columbia says will further adapt to foot shapes over time.

This it calls Omni-Max, which uses ‘a Techlite midsole, a specially designed heel and midfoot aids to create a stable platform’. Furthermore, and quite excitingly, ‘deflection domes in the forefoot and heel reduce load impact for better comfort and rebound’. And I do love a dome – tennis, thunder or otherwise.

But I jest, the bottom line is the Konos are comfy, supportive and grippy in a trainer-esque way, and I need that in my life. I dare say, (when I’m able) I could run in these (a bit, they are sandals).

So far the Konos build seems up there, they look and feel robust and the materials are all synthetic so should stand up to sea and sweat, if rinsed from time to time. The foot sole also promises to be anti-microbial (I refer you again to the opening sentence), which is nice, and the Velcro closures and heel loop making putting them on/taking them off a cinch.

Finally, at £65 and 564g (282g each) for this pair of size 45/UK 11, the Konos are relatively cheap, agile and light – for context my no-arch supporting, flappy Havaianas flip-flops cost £30 and weigh 380g. I miss them though. Expelliarmus plantar fasciitis.

  • Buy now from Columbia for £65

Sidi Shot 2S cycling shoes

Insane money but insane shoes, I think anything. The updated Sidi Shots are the company’s made-in-Italy flagship shoe, but rather than a redesign Sidi has stuck with its ‘podium-topping shoe’s’ made credentials, just updated them with ‘more comfort’ and ‘sustainable fabrics’.

What that means is a pair of Sidi’s in-house ‘Tecno 3 Push Flex’ dials (Sidi’s version of Boa dials) carry over on each shoe from the previous Shot 2, so too the C-Boost SRS carbon sole and adjustable heel retention clasp at the back of the shoe.

Only now the upper is stiffer for better power transfer (yet moulds to the foot), more breathable and crucially made from Bioveg, a material derived from recycled fabrics and cereal. Similarly the all-new in-sole is made from ‘95% recycled materials’, and claims to offer greater stability and comfort than before.

This size 45 pair weighs a little over 600g, which is middling heavy. But I’d wager as with other Sidi’s I’ve owned or tested, your grandkids will still be riding these on terraformed Mars.

  • Buy now from Saddleback for £420

All Elite smart trainers are now compatible with Zwift Cog

A new way to train indoors, even for those who have been riding with us for years.

With the latest firmware update, all Elite direct-drive trainers are now compatible with Zwift’s virtual shifting system. Not just the newest models: even riders using a first-generation Direto, Suito, or Justo can now enjoy Zwift Cog and Click.

For us, innovation means moving every cyclist forward.

What we’re into this week: Super Soaker water pistols

Super Soakers. Remember them? The rowdy adverts, the promises to shoot up to 25 feet? Well, I have a cherry tree in my garden and every year the same pair of wood pigeons decimate it before the hard, post-blossom little green bits (possibly called the fruit drop?) turn into lovely red cherries, so you can see where I’m going with the ownership of water pistols.

Anyway, being 40 I thought it’s high time I indulged some childhood desires and bought the very thing I wasn’t allowed as a kid, the Super Soaker 100. Only what’s that Ebay? It’s £134.96? (Don’t get me started on Ebay’s new stupid pricing based on adding buyer protection fees like Vinted).

Digging deeper, it appears all vintage (that is, made by Larami before Nerf bought it up) Super Soakers are stupid money. I guess many of them exploded into shards into little Jimmy’s eyes when the plastic of the pump action canister got too brittle over countless summers left in the paddling pool.

Also, it turns out some of the more powerful models were even banned as the very jets could shoot out children’s eye. I mean, at 60psi you’re asking for trouble surely.

So, now I know too much about the vintage Super Soaker market, with the upshot being I bought two more recent Super Soaker Scatter Blasters (circa 2010) to shoot the wood pigeons. Nerf-made, no pressurisation system just basic pump action. The first one leaked so I got my tenner back (the seller didn’t want a return) and then I bought another.

Their range is inferior. The pigeons are still here. The Latin for cherry tree is prunus avium, or bird cherry. Perhaps the futility’s in the name.
